Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project 'Non-Silane Coupling Agents' rests on the environmental advantage of a new technology platform of coupling agents with potential performance advantages for tire applications. The global tire and rubber companies consume $325 million in silane coupling agents each year. About half of the weight of the silane coupling agents (i.e., ~10 kTon or ~1-5% by weight of the tire) is converted to ethanol and, if not captured, released into the atmosphere as a volatile organic compound (VOC). By replacing the silane moiety in the conventional silane coupling agents with a catechol functional group, the non-silane coupling (NSC) technology completely eliminates the VOC generated during tire manufacture. If other industrial sectors that currently use silanes also adopt the catechol-based technology, ~50 kTon of annual VOC emission will be eliminated. The NSC technology introduces a disruptive replacement for the mature silane-based coupling technology, whose intellectual properties have long expired and whose manufacture is exclusively based in Asia. The NSC technology will also level the playingfield for US rubber and tire manufacturers against their competitors in developing countries, where the environmental regulations are relaxed.

This I-Corps project 'Non-Silane Coupling Agents' is a clean intellectual departure from the current silane-based technology, taking advantage of the exceptional ability of the catechol motif to form chelation on the surface of silica. The approach is fundamentally novel. The technology is the outcome of a research program sponsored by the NSF I/UCRC Center of Tire Research. The activities encompassed by the I-Corps Teams program will allow us the deep dive necessary to truly understand the customer opportunity, tailor the novel disruptive technology to meet these needs at an early R&D stage and enhances the probability of success. The R&D and business team bring together extensive experience working in the areas of rubber chemistry, technology, marketing, and business management.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcome

 

            The global tire and rubber companies consume $325 million in silane coupling agents each year. About half of the weight of the silane coupling agents (i.e., ~10 kTon or ~1-5% by weight of the tire) is converted to ethanol and, if not captured, released into the atmosphere as a volatile organic compound (VOC). By replacing the silane moiety in the conventional silane coupling agents with a catechol functional group, the non-silane coupling (NSC) technology completely eliminates the VOC generated during tire manufacture. If other industrial sectors that currently use silanes also adopt the catechol-based technology, ~50 kTon of annual VOC emission will be eliminated. The intellectual merit of the

The intellectual merit of the NSC technology is that it is a clean departure from the silane based technology. The potential broad impact and the initial hypothesis of I-Corps project “Non-Silane Coupling Agents” rest on the willingness of the tire and rubber industry to accept the NSC technology because it eliminates VOC. Our customer discovery interviews suggest that the VOC is indeed an issue that the tire manufacturers have to deal with but elimination of VOC alone is not sufficient for the tire companies to move away from the conventional silanes. They have other means to cope with the problem although these involve capital equipment investment or production cost. Elimination is “icing on the cake”. The tire companies would be more willing to accept a technology like NSC if it brings performance advantages. We discovered that an unsolved problem of silane coupling agents is that they are not sufficiently effective for coupling natural rubber and silica. This is a pivot point and aha moment for us. We have now zoomed our focus on development of a catechol-based coupling agent that is capable of coupling natural rubber and silica.  

Our interviews with tire users including car dealers and car buyers indicate that most of them do not care about VOC except the dealers and buyers of electric cars. The car dealers and buyers do think high fuel efficiency is a merit but does not make or break a deal. The electric car dealers and buyers care more about the fuel efficiency because they have to find the next charge station before the fuel runs out. Other rubber good manufacturers follow what the tire companies do. The interviews confirm that tire companies are our key initial customer.

We also interviewed the major silane and silica manufacturers. We have found that they are very receptive to the NSC technology. They have the manufacture capability and the distribution channel. They will be our partners for the NSC commercialization rather than competitors.  

  

 


Last Modified: 10/24/2019
Modified by: Li Jia
